newsitem.title: JAPAN: Securities up on multi-service account reports.
newsitem.headline: Securities up on multi-service account reports.

text.p: The securities sector rose in Tuesday morning trade, buoyed by media reports that the Finance Ministry is planning to lift a ban on securities companies offering multi-service accounts, brokers said.
As of 0142 GMT, the securities sector was at the top of the list of gaining sectors.

Shares of Daiwa Securities Co Ltd were up 56 yen at 979, the fourth-largest percentage gainer on the first section of the Tokyo bourse. Nikko Securities Co Ltd was the sixth-largest gainer, up 40 yen at 732. Nomura Securities Co Ltd jumped 50 yen to 1,640.
Financial daily Nihon Keizai Shimbun said Tuesday that the Finance Ministry is planning to lift the ban from April 1.

If the ban is lifted, customers will be able to automatically transfer profits from stock sales to a money management fund (MMF), a type of short-term bond management trust, and to trust funds investing mainly in medium-term government notes.
Customers' credit card charges and public utility fees can also be paid from the accounts, the newspaper said.
The ministry said Tuesday that it was mulling the possibility as a part of its planned "Big Bang" reforms and was likely to reach a conclusion by June at the latest.
